questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a family member who went to check on the patient after several unanswered phone calls yesterday. The family member found the patient confused and disoriented at home. The patient was holding her left arm limp at her side while trying to cook, and she was having difficulty selecting the appropriate utensils. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and tobacco use. Medications include lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 180/85 mmHg. On examination, the patient is not oriented to place or time. There is pronator drift and decreased sensation in the left upper extremity. Which of the following diagnostic test results is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with several cardiovascular risk factors presents with symptoms of acute encephalopathy secondary to a subcortical stroke, including confusion, anosognosia (unawareness of their own neurological deficit), and apraxia. The evaluation for acute stroke begins with non-contrast neuroimaging, with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain being the most likely to confirm the presence of a subcortical stroke.

Encephalopathy can occur from a variety of causes, including neurologic and other medical conditions. The differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on the patient’s past medical history and physical examination, which will often guide the diagnostic workup. Laboratory studies may reveal a toxic or metabolic etiology, like liver, kidney, or thyroid dysfunction. If seizure is suspected, an electroencephalogram (EEG) can be diagnostic. In cases where infection is suspected, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is warranted. Finally, for patients with stroke-like symptoms, neuroimaging in the form of non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) or MRI can confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urine toxicology screen:
Incorrect: While confusion can result from substance ingestion, this patient’s acute focal neurological deficits and stroke risk factors make non-contrast neuroimaging the most appropriate next step to evaluate for ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cell count analysis:
Incorrect: Although central nervous system infections may present with confusion, this patient’s focal deficits, absence of fever, and vascular risk factors are more concerning for stroke, requiring prompt neuroimaging without contrast.
❌ Electroencephalogram (EEG):
Incorrect: While confusion and focal neurological deficits can occur in seizure or post-ictal states, the presence of stroke risk factors makes non-contrast neuroimaging the priority to rule out acute ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast:
Incorrect: While CT imaging can detect many intracranial pathologies, non-contrast CT or MRI is preferred in the initial evaluation of suspected stroke to differentiate ischemic from hemorrhagic causes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son because of a right-sided weakness that started an hour ago. According to the patient’s son, his mother initially experienced dizziness and developed right arm and leg weakness shortly afterward. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin and amlodipine. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mmHg. Physical examination shows a minimally responsive patient with 0/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities. CT scan head shows left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage with a 4 mm midline shift towards the right. The patient is started on a mannitol infusion. She is most likely to develop which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient received a mannitol infusion for management of elevated intracranial pressure. Mannitol works by rapidly increasing the plasma or tubular fluid osmolality, causing water to move from the intracellular space into the vascular space or tubular lumen. As the water is excreted, hypernatremia may follow. Water movement from the intracellular space to the extracellular space may cause hyponatremia and pulmonary edema. Additional side effects of mannitol therapy include headache, nausea, and vomiting.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is an adverse effect associated with a loop or thiazide diuretics. Osmotic diuretics do not affect potassium excretion.  
❌ Hypocalciuria:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule, thereby decreasing calcium excretion in the urine. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
✅ Hypernatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule and can lead to hypercalcemia. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This patient was started on mannitol to decrease intracranial pressure. Mannitol does not affect potassium excretion and would not cause hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for ongoing management of a non-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. He was brought to the emergency department three hours ago by emergency medical services after he developed a sudden-onset intense headache at his workplace. On initial presentation, he was confused and disoriented. Shortly after, he became somnolent and was then intubated. Computerized tomography (CT) of the head revealed blood in the cortical convexities. A head CT angiogram showed a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. An endovascular coiling procedure was planned for the next day. Upon arrival at the ICU, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 76/min, respirations are set at 12/min by the ventilator, and blood pressure is 180/90 mmHg. On examination, he is pharmacologically sedated with no spontaneous movement. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggesting unstable subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as evidenced by inability to protect his airway in the setting of a thunderclap headache. Following initial stabilization, intervention for increased intracranial pressure (ICP), and neuroimaging, medical management includes correction of any underlying coagulopathy to prevent rebleeding, blood pressure control through administration of a calcium channel blocker, nimodipine, and prompt treatment of seizures with anti-seizure medication.        

With persistent increased ICP despite medical management, cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedures may be necessary. Intracranial aneurysms may be secured through endovascular coiling or stenting or open surgery clipping. Aneurysmal causes of SAH carry an elevated risk of cerebral ischemia within the first two weeks from cerebral vasospasm, which can be prevented through maintenance of euvolemia and use of nimodipine.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nimodipine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: The treatment of subarachnoid hemorrhage involves correction of any underlying coagulopathy and prevention of rebleeding; as an antiplatelet agent, aspirin increases the risk of hemorrhage, and thus should not be administered to this patient. 
❌ Hypoventilation:
Incorrect: The medical management of increased intracranial pressure from subarachnoid hemorrhage includes hyperventilation, rather than hypoventilation, elevation of the head of the bed, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy. 
❌ Hypervolemia:
Incorrect: Maintenance of euvolemia minimizes the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage, whereas hypervolemia can lead to cerebral or pulmonary edema through fluid overload.  
❌ Dextrose-containing intravenous fluid:
Incorrect: The medical management of increased intracranial pressure from subarachnoid hemorrhage includes hyperosmolar therapy, which can improve cerebral blood flow. Dextrose- and hypotonic fluids can cause cerebral edema and should be avoided in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of left arm weakness that occurred the evening before, lasting for two hours. The patient says she was cooking dinner when she suddenly dropped the saucepan and felt a tingling sensation in her left hand and arm. Her partner noticed that her smile appeared asymmetric, but her speech was normal. She rested for about an hour, and the symptoms resolved. She had no chest pain or shortness of breath. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and tobacco use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 100/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. On examination, she is alert and oriented with normal sensation to light touch over the arms bilaterally, normal movement, and normal grip strength bilaterally. There is no murmur, and besides the presence of a fast irregular rhythm, the rest of the cardiac exam is within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following additional historical features is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 77-year-old woman presents with sudden onset neurological symptoms that resolved within one hour, suggesting a transient ischemic attack, or TIA. Risk factors include tobacco use, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, carotid artery disease, atrial fibrillation, hypercoagulable disorders, and substance use. This patient with a fast irregular heart rate and TIA likely has undiagnosed atrial fibrillation as the cause of TIA. Additional signs and symptoms of atrial fibrillation include palpitations, dizziness, fatigue, and chest pain.

Symptoms concerning a TIA or stroke include sudden onset numbness, weakness, incoordination, slurred speech, language difficulties, vision changes, and headache. Risk factors for hemorrhagic stroke include a known vascular anomaly like an arteriovenous malformation in younger patients and amyloid angiopathy in older patients. Carotid artery dissection may be caused by neck trauma and lead to stroke or TIA. An ABCD2 score can be determined within the first 90 days after a TIA to stratify future stroke risk. The scoring system includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of TIA symptoms, and presence of diabetes to determine the risk of future stroke and to guide secondary prevention efforts.

Option Analysis

✅ New onset palpitations:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Easy bruising:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with a transient ischemic attack (or TIA), which can be related to hypercoagulability rather than a coagulation defect; that would lead to bruising and bleeding. Atrial fibrillation, which may present with palpitations, is the most likely cause of TIA in this patient. 
❌ Use of sulfonylureas:
Incorrect: Sulfonylureas are used as part of the treatment for patients with diabetes mellitus type 2. The main adverse effect is hypoglycemia. This patient with an irregular heart rate and TIA most likely has atrial fibrillation and not hypoglycemia as the cause of the TIA. Atrial fibrillation can present with new onset palpitations. 
❌ History of aneurysms:
Incorrect: Aneurysms can lead to hemorrhagic stroke; however, this patient with irregular fast heartbeat and TIA most likely has had a TIA secondary to emboli that led to ischemia and not bleeding. 
❌ Deep aching left arm pain:
Incorrect: Tingling and burning sensations in the extremities along with weakness may be seen with TIA or stroke. However, deep aching pain is not typically associated. It is more likely to be associated with acute MI or angina.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for ongoing monitoring following administration of intravenous (IV) tenecteplase for an ischemic stroke. She presented yesterday evening with acute-onset right-sided numbness and weakness. She has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. An initial computerized tomography (CT) of the head revealed a hypodensity in the left middle cerebral artery territory. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed corresponding restricted diffusion. Cardiac monitoring and echocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation. IV tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) was administered and symptoms improved. The patient has remained stable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 110/min and irregular, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 140/82 mmHg, BMI is 24 kg/m<sup>2</sup>  and hemoglobin A1c is 5.6%. In addition to blood pressure control and targeted therapy for hyperlipidemia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 68-year-old patient presents with symptoms related to an acute ischemic stroke, caused by atrial fibrillation. The patient was successfully treated with intravenous thrombolytic therapy. Management should then include prevention of future strokes (i.e. secondary prevention) with anticoagulation therapy.

For patients with an acute ischemic stroke who do not have contraindications, intravenous thrombolysis is first-line therapy when given if the onset of symptoms is less than 4.5 hours before beginning treatment. Mechanical thrombectomy may be appropriate for some patients. A number of other interventions should be performed for patients with ischemic stroke as they are associated with either reduced disability, complications, or recurrent strokes. These include antithrombotic therapy with aspirin started at least 24 hours after thrombolysis (not in patients with AFib on anticoagulants), DVT prophylaxis, anticoagulant therapy at discharge for atrial fibrillation, high intensity statin for lipid lowering, and blood pressure reduction after the acute phase of the stroke. Additional management includes interventions for modifiable risk factors like weight reduction and tobacco cessation.

Option Analysis

✅ Anticoagulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Carotid revascularization:
Incorrect: Carotid revascularization may be used to treat patients who have symptomatic carotid artery stenosis of more than 50% and a recent stable stroke. In this patient, the stroke was caused by AFib, which should be managed with anticoagulation. 
❌ Weight loss:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal BMI. Secondary stroke prevention through optimization of other stroke risk factors, like atrial fibrillation by anticoagulation, is more appropriate. 
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Anticoagulants are generally considered to be more effective than antiplatelet agents like clopidogrel for preventing stroke in patients with AFib. And if they are taken together, it would unnecessarily increase the risk of bleeding. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) can be an alternative for elderly patients who can't take anticoagulants. 
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Aggressive insulin treatment following stroke, especially in this patient with a normal hemoglobin A1c level, may increase the risk of hypoglycemia. Optimization of other risk factors, like atrial fibrillation through anticoagulation, is more appropriate.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided weakness. While playing with a grandchild earlier, the patient reported an intense headache followed by numbness in the left arm. There is no history of recent trauma. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 210/102 mmHg. On examination, the patient is drowsy and confused and reports nausea and a headache. Bilateral papilledema is noted. National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is 21 (range 0-42), with dense left hemiplegia with sensory and visual neglect. Computed tomography (CT) of the head is ordered. Which of the following findings would be expected on imaging?

choices.text: Biconvex-shaped hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines
Crescentic-shaped hyperdensity that crosses suture lines

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset headache, nausea, confusion, left hemiplegia, and papilledema, all pointing to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The markedly elevated blood pressure, high NIHSS score, and absence of trauma raise concern for spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). On non-contrast head CT, ICH appears as a hyperdense area within the brain parenchyma.

The differential for elevated ICP includes hemorrhage, ischemic stroke, mass lesions, and central nervous system (CNS) infections. CT findings help narrow down the cause. Hyperdense lesions suggest hemorrhage, and their shapes are often characteristic. Epidural hematomas are biconvex and do not cross suture lines, while subdural hematomas are crescentic and may cross sutures. Subarachnoid hemorrhage appears as a hyperdensity in the sulci or basal cisterns, whereas a hyperintensity within the brain parenchyma is seen with ICH.

Ischemic stroke typically appears as a hypodense area with loss of gray-white differentiation. Ring-enhancing lesions suggest a tumor or abscess, while diffuse cerebral edema may indicate meningitis or encephalitis. If infection is suspected and no mass effect is seen, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis can confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperdensity in the brain parenchyma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Biconvex-shaped hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines:
Incorrect: This finding describes an epidural hematoma, which is typically associated with trauma and not expected in a nontraumatic presentation such as this.
❌ Crescentic-shaped hyperdensity that crosses suture lines:
Incorrect: This finding describes a subdural hematoma, which generally results from head trauma, especially in older adults or those on anticoagulation.
❌ Ring-enhancing mass lesion:
Incorrect: Ring-enhancing lesions are more characteristic of abscesses or neoplasms, which are not consistent with this acute presentation.
❌ Ventriculomegaly:
Incorrect: Ventriculomegaly suggests hydrocephalus, which typically presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms such as gait disturbance or cognitive decline.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for coronary angiography. During the procedure, there is an acute onset of severe headache and vertigo. The patient becomes markedly confused and begins vomiting. Medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension, dyslipidemia, and chronic angina. Medications include aspirin, spironolactone, ramipril, bisoprolol, furosemide, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 210/110 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears confused with nystagmus, dysarthria, and dysphagia. Speech is severely impaired. There is no focal limb weakness, but an anterior-posterior rhythmic tremor of the head and upper trunk is noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast
Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of an acute cerebellar lesion, including headache, vertigo, vomiting, nystagmus, dysarthria, dysphagia, and truncal ataxia. Airway compromise is a major concern in patients with altered mental status and vomiting. The airway should be promptly assessed and secured, if necessary.       

Cerebellar lesions often cause loss of coordination, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, vision or speech disturbances, and dysphagia. On physical examination, findings may include limb ataxia on finger-to-nose or heel-to-shin testing, as well as truncal or gait ataxia.       

The first step in managing an unstable adult with a suspected cerebellar lesion is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Cerebellar involvement can impair swallowing and respiration, leading to respiratory depression and an inability to clear secretions, which increases the risk of aspiration. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required. Intravenous access should be obtained, and the patient should be placed on continuous monitoring, including heart rate, blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and cardiac telemetry.   

Option Analysis

✅ Airway assessment:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: While non-contrast head CT is appropriate to evaluate for hemorrhage in the setting of acute stroke symptoms, imaging must be preceded by assessment and stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. 
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without contrast:
Incorrect: MRI is more sensitive for detecting posterior circulation strokes but is not the first priority in a patient at risk of airway compromise. Airway protection takes precedence before obtaining advanced imaging. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) labetalol :
Incorrect: Blood pressure reduction may be considered later in stroke management. In the acute setting, elevated blood pressure is often tolerated to maintain cerebral perfusion. Immediate management should focus on airway protection. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: Thrombolytic therapy should not be administered before imaging has ruled out hemorrhage. However, this patient is at elevated risk for airway compromise and should first undergo airway assessment and stabilization.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of stroke-like symptoms. The patient states, “My face appeared twisted this morning.” She also reports persistent vertigo, difficulty walking, and impaired hearing from the left ear. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 166/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the left when asked to sit without support. Physical examination demonstrates drooping of the left face and loss of the left nasolabial fold. The patient is able to wrinkle the forehead. Further neurologic examination demonstrates partial ptosis and miosis of the left eye, nystagmus, reduced pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and right side of the body, and sensorineural hearing loss on the left. Hearing on the right side is intact. Which of the following vascular structures is most likely implicated given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent lateral pontine syndrome most likely due to the occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Clinical features of lateral pontine syndrome include:
  
  • Vestibulocerebellar symptoms such as nystagmus, vertigo, and difficulty sitting upright without support (falling to the side of lesion) 
  • Loss of pain and temperature sensation of the ipsilateral face (spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract) and contralateral trunk/limbs (spinothalamic tract) 
  • Paralysis of the face (LMN lesion vs UMN lesion in cortical stroke), ↓ lacrimation, ↓ salivation and ↓ taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to damage of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  •  Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of middle and inferior cerebellar peduncle 
  • Ipsilateral sensorineural deafness due to the occlusion of labyrinthine arteries, a branch of AICA 

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found in both the anterior and posterior communicating arteries of the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms often compress the central optic chiasm, resulting in symptoms of bitemporal hemianopsia.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the anterior cerebral artery often results in contralateral motor and sensory deficits, with the lower limbs affected more than the upper limbs.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia, secondary to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion usually damages the base of the pons, which houses the corticospinal/ corticobulbar tracts and the paramedian tegmentum. Ischemia to these structures results in quadriplegia, bulbar dysfunction (e.g., facial weakness, dysarthria), and oculomotor deficits (e.g. horizontal gaze palsy).

questions.text: An 85-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after being found on the floor in his home. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 188/94 mmHg. The patient appears conscious, but does not demonstrate spontaneous movement of the extremities and is unable to respond to voice or painful stimuli. The patient is able to blink and eye movements are restricted to the vertical plane. Magnetic resonance angiogram will most likely reveal ischemia of which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
This patient's inability to move the extremities, loss of horizontal eye movements with preserved consciousness, and loss of mouth, tongue, and facial movements, is consistent with locked-in syndrome (LIS), due to the occlusion of the basilar artery. The most vulnerable territory associated with this condition lies at the paramedian base of the pons.  

Clinical features consistent with locked-in syndrome include:  

  • Quadriplegia and inability to speak or swallow due to the involvement of corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts 
  • Preserved consciousness due to the sparing of the reticular formation 
  • Loss of horizontal eye movement due to the involvement of ocular cranial nerve nuclei and paramedian pontine reticular formation 
  • Voluntary blinking and vertical eye movements remain intact, which are controlled in the rostral portion of the brainstem  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion results in lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome characterized by vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, bulbar weakness, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Anterior spinal artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome, which typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Lateral pontine syndrome occurs secondary to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Patients typically present with signs of a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral sensorineural loss, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Basilar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner for evaluation of dizziness. While eating breakfast, she suddenly developed difficulty swallowing, accompanied by nausea and dizziness. She then vomited and has experienced repeated hiccups. Her past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes lisinopril, simvastatin, and insulin glargine. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, extraocular eye movements are intact, but horizontal nystagmus with a torsional element is present. Hearing is normal. The uvula deviates to the left, and there is decreased pain and temperature sensation on the right face and left upper extremity. Additionally, right limb ataxia is noted. Which additional signs or symptoms, if present, would confirm the location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, evidenced by acute-onset nausea, vomiting, dizziness, hiccups, dysphagia, decreased facial sensation, decreased contralateral limb sensation, and ipsilateral limb ataxia. The presence of Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) localizes the lesion to the lateral medulla rather than the medial medulla.

Patients with brainstem dysfunction may present with cranial neuropathies, respiratory changes, altered levels of consciousness, motor or sensory impairment, dysautonomia, or cerebellar signs, depending on whether it is the midbrain, pons, or medulla involved. The differential diagnosis is further refined by assessing the involvement of the nerves that control extraocular eye movements.

Diagnostic features help differentiate between lesions at various levels of the brainstem. In patients with impaired eye adduction, the presence of ptosis or weakness can distinguish between a cranial nerve III palsy, Weber syndrome, or intranuclear ophthalmoplegia. For those with impaired eye abduction, an evaluation of muscle strength may differentiate between a cranial nerve VI palsy, Millard-Gubler syndrome, and locked-in syndrome. When extraocular eye movements are impaired along with multiple cranial neuropathies, the differential diagnosis can include leptomeningeal carcinomatosis and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Finally, in patients with intact extraocular eye movements, assessing for Horner syndrome can help differentiate between lateral and medial medullary syndromes.

Option Analysis

✅ Right ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right homonymous hemianopsia:
Incorrect: This patient exhibits signs of acute lateral medullary syndrome, likely secondary to a stroke given her risk factors. Visual fields are typically normal because the optic nerve radiations are not involved. The presence of Horner syndrome would be the expected finding to confirm the lesion’s location.
❌ Expressive aphasia:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute lateral medullary syndrome, likely due to a stroke given her risk factors. Expressive language function remains normal because the cortical structures are not affected. The presence of Horner syndrome would confirm the lesion’s location.
❌ Receptive aphasia:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is most consistent with acute lateral medullary syndrome, likely secondary to stroke given her risk factors. Receptive language function is preserved because cortical structures are not involved. The presence of Horner syndrome would confirm the location of the lesion.
❌ Right facial palsy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of acute lateral medullary syndrome, likely secondary to stroke given her risk factors. Facial muscle strength would be normal as cranial nerve VII is localized to the pons. The presence of Horner syndrome would confirm the location of the lesion.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right arm weakness. The symptoms were present when the patient awoke, accompanied by drooling and a right facial droop. When attempting to rise from bed, the patient collapsed and has been difficult to arouse since. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications are metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, respirations are 8-10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 188/95 mmHg. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 7. The patient opens his eyes and withdraws the left extremities to pain but has no verbal response. There is flaccid paralysis on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast
Flatten the head of the bed

questions.solution:
The presence of the Cushing triad (e.g., bradycardia, irregular respirations, hypertension) along with a low GCS suggests increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and indicates the need for intubation, with consideration of transient hyperventilation.

Increased ICP refers to intracranial pressure greater than 20 millimeters of mercury, which can occur due to an increase in the blood, brain, or cerebrospinal fluid compartment. Acute management begins with stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. This may include intubation and mechanical ventilation when indicated, establishment of intravenous access, and continuous monitoring of vital signs and cardiac rhythm (telemetry).

Further management involves formal ICP monitoring and targeted interventions. Elevating the head of the bed to 30–45 degrees promotes venous outflow and reduces ICP. Hyperosmolar therapy and analgesia may be administered as appropriate. Hyperventilation may temporarily reduce ICP by lowering carbon dioxide levels and inducing cerebral vasoconstriction, but it should be used with caution, as prolonged vasoconstriction may compromise cerebral perfusion and lead to ischemia.

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: A CT should be obtained to evaluate for the cause of this patient's neurological symptoms, but imaging should follow initial stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with depressed mental status and inadequate respiratory effort, securing the airway takes precedence.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging should be obtained to evaluate for the cause of this patient's neurological symptoms, but it should follow initial stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with depressed mental status and inadequate respiratory effort, securing the airway takes precedence.
❌ Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation may be due to an ischemic stroke, thrombolytic therapy should not be administered until intracranial hemorrhage has been excluded by neuroimaging. Additionally, because the patient awoke with stroke symptoms, the exact time of onset is unknown, which likely places the patient outside the recommended window for thrombolysis.
❌ Flatten the head of the bed:
Incorrect: In patients with suspected increased intracranial pressure, the head of the bed should be elevated to promote venous drainage and reduce intracranial pressure. Flattening the bed may worsen cerebral edema.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset vertigo, gait disturbance, and a stabbing pain on the right side of her face. The patient does not have fever, weight loss, chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the right when asked to sit without support. Neurological exam is significant for partial ptosis and miosis of the right eye, nystagmus, and reduced pain and temperature sensation on the right face and left body. The patient’s voice sounds hoarse and she does not gag with oral tongue blade insertion. Hearing is intact bilaterally. Which of the following anatomic structures is the most likely site pathology given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological findings are consistent with lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome. This condition involves reduced blood supply to some (or all) of the following structures of the dorsolateral medulla including the inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, fibers or nuclei of nerve IX or X, spinal nucleus and tract of V, spinothalamic tract, and sympathetic pathway. The dorsolateral medulla receives its blood supply from the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.  

Clinical features of lateral medullary syndrome include:
 
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex, and hiccups due to the involvement of nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X, XI)
  • Vomiting, vertigo and nystagmus, attributable to vestibular nuclei involvement
  • Diminished pain and temperature sensation of the contralateral body and ipsilateral face due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract and spinal trigeminal nucleus 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to involvement of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of inferior cerebellar peduncle 

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral medulla  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterolateral thalamus  :
Incorrect: A pure sensory stroke often occurs secondary to malperfusion of the ventral posterolateral and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus–a key cerebral structure that relays sensory information regarding proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals present with numbness of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus).  
❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome. This condition typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Basal pons:
Incorrect: Hypoperfusion of the basal pons results from occlusion of penetrating arteries, leading to the development of dysarthria (clumsy hand syndrome). Affected individuals present with facial weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and weakness of the hand ipsilateral to the lesion. Sensory deficits are absent in patients with this condition.  
❌ Parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and/or middle cerebral artery (MCA). Malperfusion of the parietal lobe may result in numbness; however, a stroke of the nondominant hemisphere manifests with contralateral neglect, while infarction of the dominant side manifests with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with his spouse due to right-sided weakness that began 30 minutes ago. According to the patient’s spouse, he had just returned home from work when he suddenly could not move his right arm or leg. Past medical and surgical history are unremarkable. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 172/95 mmHg. On physical examination, he has 0/5 strength in the right upper and right lower extremity with a left gaze preference. A CT-brain without contrast and chest x-ray are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset right-sided hemiplegia and left-gaze deviation. A CT brain is negative for acute intracranial hemorrhage. In an acute ischemic stroke setting, intravenous tPA should be administered to all eligible patients within three hours since symptom onset and to a selective group of eligible acute stroke patients within four and a half hours.  

Thrombolytic medications (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase, reteplase) are recombinant tissue plasminogen activators indicated for treating massive pulmonary embolism causing hemodynamic instability, acute ischemic stroke, as well as early myocardial infarction. They work by directly or indirectly increasing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin and dissolving the fibrin clot.    

Absolute contraindications to thrombolytic medications include acute intracranial hemorrhage, prior stroke or head trauma within the past three months, systolic blood pressure >185 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure >110 mmHg, history of bleeding diathesis, or a known arteriovenous malformation. However, these medications must be carefully administered since they increase the risk of bleeding. If the patient in question is not a candidate for thrombolysis, the next best step would be to perform mechanical thrombectomy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer clopidogrel:
Incorrect: ADP receptor inhibitors such as clopidogrel are potent anti-platelet inhibitors and are more commonly used in myocardial infarction or after coronary artery stenting. They are not used in the setting of acute ischemic stroke.
❌ Obtain echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Cardiac echocardiogram can show evidence of a patent foramen ovale, enabling clots within veins to travel into the arteries and become lodged in the brain, leading to an ischemic stroke. However, it is not the first-line management for this patient presenting with acute ischemic stroke. 
✅ Administer intravenous alteplase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: A surgical thrombectomy is a treatment option for patients with ischemic stroke outside the window for tPA administration. Thrombolysis is the preferred first-line treatment in patients with acute ischemic stroke presenting within the tPA window. Furthermore, surgical thrombectomy can be done in patients with contraindications to thrombolysis. 
❌ Administer warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor used in treating patients with deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Warfarin is not used in the acute setting because it takes time for previously made coagulation factors to degrade and because of the chance of warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for altered mental status. Earlier that afternoon during a meeting, the patient suddenly appeared confused, staring at his right hand. When asked to look at the slide on the left side of the screen, the patient looked to the right instead, appearing confused about which side was left. The patient was unable to continue taking notes and asked for “You know, the thing you use to write with.” Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. On exam, the patient is alert with mild word-finding difficulty and is unable to write. Sensory and motor exams are normal. Which additional symptom would most likely confirm the location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
This 49-year-old patient presents with symptoms consistent with Gerstmann syndrome, including agraphia, left-right disorientation, and possible finger agnosia. These findings are commonly associated with lesions of the left angular gyrus. Acalculia, another hallmark of Gerstmann syndrome, may be identified by asking the patient to complete simple arithmetic tasks.        

The clinical presentation of cortical lesions varies based on the location of involvement. Dominant symptoms help narrow the differential diagnosis: aphasia (impaired speech production or comprehension), anopsia (visual field deficits), agnosia (inability to recognize objects, people, or stimuli despite intact sensory function), or neglect. In contrast, subcortical lesions often manifest as motor abnormalities (e.g., weakness, involuntary movements), hemisensory loss, or cognitive and behavioral changes (e.g., memory impairment, apathy, hypersexuality, hyperphagia).        

When a cortical lesion presents with agnosia, it is important to identify the specific type. Finger agnosia (inability to distinguish or recognize one’s fingers), along with acalculia, agraphia, and left-right disorientation, suggests a lesion in the dominant (typically left) angular gyrus. In contrast, prosopagnosia (inability to recognize familiar faces) is associated with bilateral lesions of the fusiform gyri in the occipitotemporal region.   

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to perform calculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inability to recognize faces :
Incorrect: Prosopagnosia, or the inability to recognize familiar faces, is typically associated with lesions of the bilateral fusiform gyri. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia. 
❌ Hemiballismus:
Incorrect: Hemiballismus can be seen in basal ganglia lesions. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia. 
❌ Hyperphagia:
Incorrect: Hyperphagia, often accompanied by hyperorality and visual agnosia, is a feature of Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can pr
❌ Impaired delayed recall:
Incorrect: Impaired delayed recall is a finding more consistent with lesions affecting the hippocampus. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty speaking. The patient was dining with a friend when she suddenly could not find words to continue the story she was telling. Past medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 188/98 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears alert and anxious, saying phrases like, “Friend tea today” and “Speak trouble.” The patient can follow written directions but cannot write. There is drift in the right arm. Which additional test is key to differentiating the location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of expressive aphasia, including short, poorly formed sentences, word-finding difficulty, and non-fluent speech with improper grammar. To distinguish between Broca and transcortical motor aphasia, ask the patient to repeat words or phrases.       

Assessment of the type of aphasia can help you localize the lesion. There are four types of aphasia: expressive, receptive, conduction, and global. While all will present with communication difficulties, each will differ in terms of speech production. An important physical examination maneuver is to ask the patient to repeat words or phrases. If the patient cannot repeat, the differential diagnosis includes global aphasia, conduction aphasia, Wernicke receptive aphasia, and Broca expressive aphasia. If the patient can repeat, the differential diagnosis includes transcortical motor or sensory aphasia.         

Another important physical examination maneuver is to ask the patient to read and write words and phrases. Patients with expressive aphasia will display intact reading skills but will struggle with writing, while those with receptive aphasia will be unable to read or write.    


Option Analysis

✅ Repetition of words and phrases:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Orientation questions :
Incorrect: Orientation questions assess awareness of time, place, and person, but they are not particularly useful for localizing aphasia. This patient is alert, and the phrases spoken do not suggest disorientation. The ability to repeat phrases, however, could help differentiate between Broca aphasia and transcortical motor aphasia.  
❌ Visual field assessment:
Incorrect: Visual field testing is an important component of the neurological examination and can indicate damage to the occipital lobe or optic pathways. However, aphasia is more likely related to dysfunction in the frontal or temporal lobes, which are involved in language processing. Testing for repetition of words and phrases is more specific for localizing the lesion within the language network.  
❌ Finger-to-nose test:
Incorrect: The finger-to-nose test evaluates cerebellar function and is used to assess for dysmetria. However, aphasia is more likely related to dysfunction in the frontal or temporal lobes, which are involved in language processing. Testing for repetition of words and phrases is more specific for localizing the lesion within the language network.  
❌ Reading aloud:
Incorrect: Reading aloud assesses fluency and comprehension in the context of language function. However, it does not provide additional information in this case since the patient has already demonstrated non-fluent language and the preserved ability to read.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) for evaluation after being assaulted. Paramedics report the patient was strangled by an assailant and was found unresponsive at the scene. A cervical collar was applied prior to arrival at the ED. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 177/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 67% on room air. The patient appears cyanotic and responds to a sternal rub. There is a large ecchymosis around the left orbit and a large left scalp hematoma. There is also significant ecchymosis and swelling of the neck. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 6, and pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Intravenous access is established, and supplemental oxygen is applied via non-rebreather. Rapid sequence intubation is attempted, but upon entering the airway, marked edema and bleeding is noted, and the vocal cords cannot be visualized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head and neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents following a traumatic neck injury with evidence of airway instability. Rapid sequence intubation is attempted, but the patient cannot be intubated orally. Therefore, the best next step in management is to perform an emergent cricothyrotomy to stabilize the airway prior to performing a CTA of the head and neck to evaluate for blunt cerebrovascular injury, which can be life-threatening.       

Blunt cerebrovascular injury, or BCVI, refers to damage to the carotid or vertebral arteries following blunt head or neck trauma. These injuries are often caused by motor vehicle collisions, falls, strangulation, or direct trauma to the neck. BCVI is divided into 5 grades based on the luminal narrowing of the vessels. BCVI has the potential to induce thrombus formation, vascular occlusion, and vascular wall hematomas, which can result in serious complications like a stroke.        

Acute management for all patients presenting with possible BCVI follows standard trauma protocols starting with an ABCDE assessment. Since most patients with BCVI present with associated neck injuries that compromise the airway, it is imperative to secure the airway as soon as possible and to anticipate a difficult airway. In addition to standard rapid sequence intubation, emergent cricothyrotomy may be necessary if the patient cannot be intubated.        

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources   

Option Analysis

✅ Cricothyrotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Percutaneous transtracheal jet ventilation:
Incorrect: Percutaneous transtracheal jet ventilation is an emergent airway strategy used in pediatric patients who require an alternative to cricothyrotomy. It is not the definitive airway management strategy for this adult patient.  
❌ Fiberoptic awake intubation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of marked edema of the airway, and the vocal cords cannot be visualized. Fiberoptic awake intubation is unlikely to be successful.  
❌ Supraglottic device:
Incorrect: Supraglottic devices (e.g. laryngeal mask airway (LMA)) can be used as a temporizing measure for patients prior to definitive airway management. This patient has evidence of marked edema of the airway, and LMA is unlikely to be effective.  
❌ Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head and neck:
Incorrect: CTA of the head and neck should be obtained for this patient to rule out blunt cerebrovascular injury, but definitive airway management is necessary first, given this patient's unstable airway.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after a fall that occurred while snowboarding. The patient was traveling at high speed without a helmet when he hit a rock. A cervical collar was placed before arrival. The patient has no significant past medical history, and he does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Upon primary survey, the patient is slurring his words but can report neck pain. Bilateral breath sounds are auscultated on pulmonary exam. There are 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 15, and vertical nystagmus is noted in the pupils bilaterally. Intravenous access is established. On secondary survey, bruising and swelling are noted on the anterior face. There is reproducible tenderness to palpation of the cervical spine. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) imaging of the head and neck shows a left vertebral artery dissection. Which of the following best describes this blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient has experienced a significant injury and presents with nystagmus and slurring of his words, which are indications of disruption of the posterior circulation (vertebrobasilar) vessels that supply the cerebellum. He is diagnosed with a vertebral artery dissection by CT angiography (CTA). Grading depends on the extent of the injury. Vertebral artery dissection is considered a grade II blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI).       

BCVI refers to damage to a carotid or vertebral artery following blunt head or neck trauma. BCVI can be divided into 5 grades based on the luminal narrowing of the vessels seen on CTA. BCVI has the potential to cause thrombus formation, vascular occlusion, or vascular wall hematomas, which can result in serious complications like a stroke. CTA imaging should be performed on patients with blunt neck trauma when there is high suspicion of BCVI based on history and physical examination or based on the Denver Screening Criteria in asymptomatic patients. Based on CTA findings, the BCVI can be graded according to the table above.   

Option Analysis

❌ Grade I:
Incorrect: A grade I blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) is diagnosed if CTA imaging shows vertebral or carotid artery injury with less than 25 percent luminal narrowing. These injuries are considered mild.  
✅ Grade II:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Grade III:
Incorrect: A grade III blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) is diagnosed if CTA imaging shows a pseudoaneurysm of the vertebral or carotid artery. This means that there is some damage to the arterial wall causing it to weaken and balloon.  
❌ Grade IV :
Incorrect: A grade IV blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) occurs when there is complete occlusion of the vertebral or carotid artery. This injury pattern poses an elevated risk of brain ischemia and stroke. 
❌ Grade V :
Incorrect: A grade V blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) occurs when there is evidence of transection of the vertebral or carotid artery with contrast extravasation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after tripping and falling down two flights of stairs. A cervical collar was applied by paramedics before arrival. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia for which he takes amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 185/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Upon primary survey, the patient speaks in clear, full sentences and reports pain in his upper back and neck. The patient has bilateral breath sounds and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 15. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Intravenous access is established. Which of the following findings, if seen on secondary survey, would indicate the need for computed tomography angiography (CTA) imaging of the head and neck?

choices.text: Bruising to the anterior chest wall and clavicle

questions.solution:
This patient presents after falling down two flights of stairs with non-specific cranio-cervical injuries. If he is found to have miosis of the left pupil on secondary survey, a finding which can be seen in patients with Horner syndrome (рtoѕiѕ, miοѕiѕ, anhidrosis), then emergent CTA should be performed.        

Blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) is most often seen in patients who have had motor vehicle collisions, falls, strangulation, or direct blows to the neck. Physical examination may show cervical-cranial injury patterns such as soft tissue ecchymoses, cervical spine tenderness, or cranio-facial deformity. Patients may have focal neurologic deficits such as weakness, diminished sensation, or findings of Horner syndrome (BCVI of the carotid artery can disrupt the periarterial sympathetic plexus and lead to Horner syndrome).   

Patients with any clinical symptom or sign suggestive of blunt cerebrovascular iոϳurу or with unexplained neurologic symptoms, like the patient in this vignette, should have a CTA. Asymptomatic patients with any of the following risk factors for BCVI from the Denver Criteria* should also have CTA performed:    
  •  Potential arterial hemorrhage from the neck, mouth, or ear  
  •  Expanding сеrviϲаl hematoma  
  •  Cervical brսit in a patient younger than 50 years of age  
  •  Focal or lateralizing neurologic deficit (e.g., hеmiраrеsis, transient ischemic attack, Horner syndrome, oculosympathetic paresis, vertebrobasilar insufficiency).  
 *The Denver criteria also include certain other risk factors if they occur in association with a high energy transfer mechanism.   



Option Analysis

✅ Miosis of the left pupil:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Epistaxis:
Incorrect: Epistaxis alone would not be an indication for additional imaging via CTA of the head and neck.  
❌ Periorbital tenderness:
Incorrect: Tenderness to palpation in the periorbital region may be due to injuries other than blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) in a patient with multiple injuries; therefore, periorbital tenderness alone would not be an indication for additional imaging via CTA of the head and neck. 
❌ Bruising to the anterior chest wall and clavicle:
Incorrect: Bruising to the anterior chest wall and clavicle alone would not be an indication that additional imaging via CTA of the head and neck should be performed.  
❌ Bruising to the bilateral midface:
Incorrect: Bruising to the bilateral midface alone would not be an indication that additional imaging via CTA of the head and neck should be performed.

questions.text:
A 36- year-old woman presents to the clinic with a fever, malaise, and headache for two weeks. She has been sexually active with her partner for one year. Her past medical history includes untreated HIV. The patient drinks 4-5 beers daily and uses both cocaine and marijuana. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. An LP and India ink stain reveal evidence of cryptococcal meningitis, and the patient is initiated on appropriate antifungal therapy. One week later, her laboratory investigations reveal the findings below. Which of the following is the pharmacological agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin      9  g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  4,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  90,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient has cryptococcal meningitis and develops leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia following initiation of antifungal therapy. The treatment of choice for cryptococcal meningitis includes induction therapy consisting of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine. A major adverse effect associated with flucytosine therapy is bone marrow suppression.    

Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that inhibits both DNA and RNA biosynthesis by deaminating 5-fluorocytosine to 5-fluorouracil, resulting in fungal cell death. It also prevents protein synthesis by a separate mechanism involving the incorporation of a 5-FU metabolite into fungal RNA. Indications for flucytosine use (in combination with other antifungal agents) include severe cryptococcal meningitis, meningoencephalitis, and severe candidiasis.  



Adverse effects of flucytosine are primarily hematological, hepatic, and gastrointestinal. In particular, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are dose-limiting complications.


Option Analysis

❌ Terbinafine:
Incorrect: Terbinafine use is associated with hepatotoxicity and gastrointestinal disturbances. It is not indicated in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis and does not induce bone marrow suppression. 
❌ Griseofulvin :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin use is limited to the treatment of superficial dermatophyte infections. Adverse effects include gastrointestinal disturbances, headache, photosensitivity, and hypersensitivity. It is not indicated in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. 
❌ Fluconazole :
Incorrect: Fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis as a component of consolidation therapy. Hepatic injury following azole use is common and can range from mild elevation of transaminases to hepatitis. 
❌ Amphotericin B :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis that is highly nephrotoxic. Flucytosine is a more likely cause of bone marrow failure. 
✅ Flucytosine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man admitted to the inpatient unit is found to have an acute reduction in urine output over the last 24 hours. He was diagnosed with cryptococcal meningitis one week ago and was initiated on a treatment regimen involving amphotericin B and flucytosine. His medical history includes AIDS and IgA nephropathy. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Mucous membranes appear moist. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below. Which of the following is the target of the pharmacological agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   135 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.9 mg/dL 
 Mg  2.0 g/dL 
 BUN  30
questions.solution:
This patient with recent treatment for cryptococcal meningitis, presents with evidence of acute kidney injury, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia consistent with amphotericin B induced nephrotoxicity.   Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol–a key component of the fungal cell membrane–creating “micropores”, increasing cellular permeability. It is fungicidal at high doses and fungistatic at lower concentrations and clinically indicated in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis, cryptococcal meningitis, invasive candidiasis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis and leishmaniasis.  

Amphotericin B is available in both conventional and liposomal formulations and is only administered intravenously. Lipid-based formulations are considerably less nephrotoxic and preferred in patients at increased risk of developing acute kidney injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fungal cell membrane :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fungal cell wall :
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit beta-glucan synthesis (a component of the fungal cell wall). The most common adverse effects associated with echinocandins include gastrointestinal disturbance. 
❌ Microtubules :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It does not adversely affect kidney function or cause electrolyte abnormalities. 
❌ Lanosterol synthesis :
Incorrect: Terbinafine is used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is involved in lanosterol synthesis. Terbinafine use can cause gastrointestinal disturbance.
❌ Nucleic acid synthesis :
Incorrect: Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by converting 5- flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil. Although it is a component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it does not cause acute kidney injury. Adverse effects encountered with flucytosine use include bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal disturbance.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for fever and low back pain that radiates down her legs and is associated with numbness and weakness. She states her symptoms began three days ago and have progressively worsened to the point where she can no longer ambulate without assistance. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The spine is tender to palpation in the lumbar region at L4/L5. The lower extremities have decreased sensation to touch, diminished reflexes, and 3/5 muscle strength. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,500/µL (13.5 × 109/L). Blood cultures are collected. Which of the following, if present, would be a risk factor associated with the development of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of fever, lumbar back pain with radiation down the legs, associated numbness and weakness, spinal tenderness on exam, and systemic signs of infection suggests a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). Injection drug use is a known risk factor for spinal epidural abscess since it can introduce bacteria directly into the bloodstream, leading to hematogenous spread and abscess formation, particularly in the spine due to its rich blood supply.        

Physical examination in a patient with SEA will demonstrate signs and symptoms of local inflammation at the site of the abscess as well as systemic signs of infection. Back pain is the most common presenting symptom and is present in 70 percent to 100 percent of cases. Fever is an important diagnostic clue but can be absent on presentation. Spinal tenderness to palpation can be seen. Neurologic deficits are found in up to half of the cases of spinal epidural abscess and may include motor weakness, radiculopathy, and bowel and bladder dysfunction. Once paralysis develops, it may quickly become irreversible. Thus, urgent intervention is required if progression of weakness or other neurologic findings are detected. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast is the preferred imaging test because it is often positive early in the course of the infection, and it provides the best visualization of the location and extent of inflammatory changes.  



Option Analysis

❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: This patient with low back pain, lower extremity weakness, fever, and spinal tenderness most likely has a spinal epidural abscess. Tobacco use is not associated with the development of a spinal epidural abscess.  
❌ Recent travel history:
Incorrect: This patient with low back pain, lower extremity weakness, fever, and spinal tenderness most likely has a spinal epidural abscess. While travel can expose individuals to endemic diseases, it is less likely to cause an acute spinal epidural abscess without other risk factors being present, like immunosuppression. 
❌  Recent insect bite:
Incorrect: Insect bites can transmit infections such as West Nile virus, which can cause neuroinvasive disease. However, patients typically present with meningoencephalitis rather than a localized infection like a spinal epidural abscess, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.  
✅ Injection drug use:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Asthma controlled with steroid inhaler:
Incorrect: Long-term use of high dose oral or intravenous glucocorticoids can lead to immunosuppression and increased risk of spinal epidural abscess. However, use of inhaled steroids would not significantly increase the risk.
